dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's say Gale's right. Some sick- fuck-Agatha Christie-wannabe set him  up, arranged like the perfect murder.  Why send a magazine journalist proof  a few hours before he's won? Doesn't  make sense.

dialogues.text: Why does he give a shit?

Make sure he  sits six years on death row for the  murder -- a place he's made a public  career of loathing. And then just  let him die, die knowing everyone  will remember him with disgust. dialogues.text: Bitsey gestures to the tape, makes a need-I-say-more face

dialogues.text: Then why release it?

dialogues.text: If the mouse dies the game's over.  Maybe the cat's enjoying himself.  Or...

dialogues.text: The 'cat' is a fucking psychopath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Oh, and bring in Miss Bloom's  original when that's done. (entering, to Bitsey) Don't blame you for not watching  that twice.

dialogues.text: He goes to his desk and starts sifting through papers.

dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep afterwards.

dialogues.text: I understand. I generally tell folks  I'm no more afraid of the grim reaper  than I am of a Presbyterian on  Mother's Day. But watching your  tape... well. I had to keep tellin'  myself 'that's not Constance' just  to get through. (a beat) Unfortunately, others may argue the  same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it's her kitchen, in her  house.

dialogues.text: Currently home to Weirdos  Incorporated. Arguably, that tape  could have been made by anybody with  twenty dollars and a tolerance for  vulgarity.

dialogues.text: But it will at least get us a  postponement?

dialogues.text: I hope so, Miss Bloom, I certainly  hope so. But you've got to remember  that there's a machine a runnin'.  And come six o'clock tomorrow mornin'  that machine wants to be fed.

dialogues.text: The Clerk puts the last of the money back into the suitca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All here, Mr. Belyeu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Clerk) Thank you, Joshua. (to Bitsey) To add to our troubles, your own  credibility may come into question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk exits.

dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been fraternizin' with the  condemned. In the court's eyes, he's  the most likely candidate to have  put you onto the tape. He's a  persuasive man, you're a out-of-state  woman -- it don't look good on paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But someone put it in my hotel room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fact for which we have no evidence.

dialogues.text: A very professional-looking assistant enters, hands Bitse her video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Bobbi.

dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.text: (standing) Well, let's not start readin' Kafka  just yet. Could we find a sympathetic  judge. I'll file within the hour.  You headin' back over to Ellis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) Yeah.

dialogues.text: Fine. I'll call over at the motel  later and give you an update.

At the end of another short hall, she comes to the elevat pushes the call button. As she waits, she looks out an  adjacent window at the capital in the rain. She remembers something, looks down -- she has her purse but no umbrell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.text: She heads back toward Belyeu's office. As she turns the corner, she sees the older cowboy enter Belyeu and Crane office.

dialogues.text: Bitsey hurries umbrella-less through the rain to the rent car parked in the loading zone.

dialogues.text: Bitsey opens the door. Zack's in the passenger seat. She  doesn't bother to sit.

dialogues.text: Did you see the cowboy go in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.text: Follow him. Find out who he is, where  he lives -- what he --

dialogues.text: How are you gonna get to Ellis?

dialogues.text: A taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zack makes a face.

dialogues.text: A taxi makes its way through the hundreds of protesters a press that now gather along the drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitsey, wet and hugging herself, paces in front of David. She's upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Calm down. You have to  sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the loudspeaker:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visitors need to stay seated.

dialogues.text: She sits.

dialogues.text: (to the microphone  above) Sorry. (to Bitsey) Look at me. He's not your man. His  name is Dusty Wright, DeathWatch  Director before Constance. He's a  'bullhorner,' a zealot who thinks a  good demonstration has to end in a  riot and arrests. 'Almost martyrs  don't mean shit.' They fired him.  Constance kept him in the  organization, and he loved her for  it. The man adored her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why was he following us? Why  was he at Belyeu and Crane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Benny used to work A.C.L.U.  cases together, until Dusty punched  a clansman in a federal court. Benny  sometimes still gives him work,  probably had him follow you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. David looks up at the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To make sure you honored your  agreement, one for which there's no  contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would've said something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a lawyer, Ms. Bloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Dusty was jealous because you  were seeing Constance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't 'seeing' Constance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She died... she had your sperm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more complicated than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rotates.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: David sits in a lawn chair beside his Volvo. The tailgate down, serving as a makeshift table for a coffee thermos a whiskey bottle. David stares off down the alley, clearly pain. He holds a child's drawing.

dialogues.speaker: DRAWING
dialogues.text: Has Gaudi's church and a matador in background. Prominent the foreground are three labeled figures: Sharon ("Mommy" Chase ("Me") and a dark-haired man ("Papa Jorge"). Jorge dressed in a tux, Sharon seems to wear a bridal gown.

dialogues.text: The atmosphere is tense. Dusty Wright sits on a deskholdi a red Magic Marker, the matron sits behind it. They look at the college guy, who closely watches a compu screen. In the center of the room, a middle-aged priest sits and  quietly prays while holding the hands of an overweight wo she murmurs quiet affirmations. Finally, the college guy looks up at Dusty, nods. The roo occupants all exchange glances. Dusty walks to the photo wall, marks a cross through the  photo of Jo Ann Johnson, then walks to the back office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constance, wrapped in an afghan, sleeps on a futon. She's shockingly anemic. Dusty kneels beside her, watches her sleep. After a beat, she wakes with a slight jolt -- like someone whose been  fighting to stay awake. She looks at him, then sees the m in his hand. She looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I can feel is envy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty stands, goes to the alley window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David's Volvo is parked just outside the window. David si in a lawn chair behind it. David looks awful.

dialogues.text: In the window, Dusty holds up the marker. David nods.

dialogues.text: David sits on the porch holding a drink, a bottle of Blac Bush in the chair beside him. He's staring at nothing. Constance comes out the open sliding glass door, wearing turtleneck sweater and wrapped in her afghan. She goes to the chair beside him, picks up the bottle and sits. They  silently survey the yard, the sunset. She hugs the bottle he sips his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember those Kubler-Ross stages,  the ones the dying go through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denial, anger, bargaining, depression,  and acceptance. Where are you?

dialogues.text: Denial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denial's my personal favorite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole idea of there being a  process makes me tired. I'm not up  to the job of Dying Person. Marveling  at blades of grass. Lecturing  strangers to relish every moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mending bridges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mending bridges. Confessing regrets.  Uuuggh.

dialogues.text: No regrets?

dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take that back. I wish I had a child.

dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.text: I'm sorry, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches over and puts her hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I just wish I would have  risked more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has the bottle in her other hand, looks at it, takes swig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a face,  swallowing hard) Uumm, also not enough sex. Should  have had more sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's... not every... yeah, you  should have had more sex.

dialogues.text: A pity lay. No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn, their eyes meet, hold.

dialogues.text: Constance and David are in bed making love. He's on top, hand supports her head, the other strokes her face. They tenderly kiss. He starts moving, gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.text: He kisses her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good.

dialogues.text: Moves up to her ear.

dialogues.text: Talk to me. Let me hear your voice.

dialogues.text: Hold me tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.text: Tight... I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.text: He stops moving, kisses her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stop. Stay in me. Please stay  in me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves again, slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh. I'm staying.

dialogues.text: I need to feel you inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. I'm inside. I'm not pulling  out.

dialogues.text: I'm so tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired of being afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh.

dialogues.text: Help me.

dialogues.text: I'm here. It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me. Please. Make it stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh. I'm here. I'm here.

dialogues.text: She's awake as David enters. He opens the curtains, sets glass of water beside bottles on the nightstand. He crawl on top of the covers, spoons her, nuzzles the back of her head.

dialogues.text: How do you feel about last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rescued. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I have a reason to get out of  bed. Ironic, huh?

dialogues.text: David goes to the pay phone against the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constance stands in a bathrobe beside her shower. Turns t water on. She's caught in a thought, bites her lip. She turns the water off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sits in a lounger speaking to someone on his right. He's sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's say they move back from Spain,  that I somehow got my one weekend a  month. Would it matter? By high  school, I'd be his weak spot, the  focus of locker room jabs, embarrassed  pride. In college there'd be late- night angst: 'What if I turn out  like the old man?' Holidays would be  forced smiles and unscheduled exits.  I mean, what girl comes home with  you if there's talk that Pops is a  rapist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand the idea of being his  model of failure. Without him, I  drink. To cover the hole. To prove  to myself he's better off without  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: ROTATING CAMERA. The policeman holds the light.

dialogues.text: (a loudspeaker voice) Gale, time's up.

dialogues.text: ROTATING CAMERA. Bitsey's agitated. David's drained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there has to be someone. Someone  with a motive, who knew you both.  Someone who visited that morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could answer... we wouldn't be  having this conversation. It's why I  need you, why I chose you. You have  my story, now... (mimicking her delivery) 'Go.'

dialogues.text: There's not enough time.

dialogues.text: The guard approaches.

dialogues.text: You'll find time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that's not what I meant.  You should have done this earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not here to save me. You're  here to save my son's memory of his  father -- that's all I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to let them kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David moves to the back of the cage to be handcuffed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We live to stop death. Eating,  inventing, loving, praying, fighting,  killing -- choose a verb. All to  stall this evil, Job's 'king of  terrors.' But what do we really know  about it? Nobody comes back. There's  a point, when your mind out-lives  its obsessions, when your habits  survive your dreams, when your  losses... You wonder, maybe death is  a gift. All I know is that by this  time tomorrow, I'll be better off.  What I don't know is why. (exits the cage) Goodbye, Bitsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard escorts him away. When he's out of earshot:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Goodbye, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guard hangs up a phone and leans out the door.

At the end of the drive, on the left, Bitsey sees a sign  leaning against a camper: "Save David Gale." It catches r its letters run.

dialogues.text: The restaurant's crowded. A Church of Christ couple (50s) eat without comment. The man's T-shirt reads, "It's Simpl You Kill, You Get Killed." In the booth beside them sit Bitsey and Zack, their dinne largely untouched. Bitsey watches three sleazy JOURNALIST at a table not far from theirs.

dialogues.text: I got it. I got it. You could have  corporate sponsors. Volkswagen for  Bundy, Home Depot for Gacy. And 'The  David Gale Execution, brought to you  by...'

dialogues.text: They find this hilarious. Bitsey looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Nine hours, 52 minutes.

dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pouring rain. As Bitsey and Zack hurry toward their rooms they see Belyeu getting out of his Cadillac. He carries  Bitsey's umbrella and opens his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The highway forks off to another. An arrow sign at the fo reads: "TDC Ellis Unit/8 Miles."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitsey smells something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rental car, smoke pouring from the engine, clunks to dead roll, stops. Bitsey jumps out, VHS cassette in hand. She doesn't close the door. Starts running. Bitsey runs down the middle of the two-lane highway. The  rental car in the b.g. recedes into the mist -- visibilit is no more than fifty yards. The sounds of her breathing SHOES HITTING the PAVEMENT ECHO into the mist. She runs, and runs. A car comes up quickly behind her. Its HORN BLARES. She t starts to wave it down. The driver SITS ON his HORN, swer around her onto highway's shoulder and drives on. She runs. Runs past an abandoned vegetable stand. Runs pa a sleepy farmhouse. She runs, and runs. She slows, out of strength, looks up and down the highway Both in front and behind, it leads straight into the mist tunnel of fog. She stumbles on, a final effort. She runs. Sees something. Stops cold. Coming toward her in the distance are small flashing ligh They rise on hill and then fall behind another. They appear again. Soon, she can make out the form of an  ambulance, and its highway patrol escort. The vehicles mo slowly toward her, without sirens, as deathly quiet as th cargo. She stands to the side of the road as they approac The highway patrol vehicle and the ambulance -- marked "T Department of Corrections" -- pass silently in SLOW MOTIO She watches as they disappear back into the mist. In SLOW MOTION, she screams, falls to her knees wailing, but we c hear her. We HEAR NOTHING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g., Dusty walks out the front door carrying two  large suitcases. On his desk in the f.g. is a radiator ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belyeu makes his way through the departure hall carrying aluminum suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: Roberts and the Court TV "breaking news" logo are on the  screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to camera) Here's what we know so far. Last  night, News Magazine posted on their  web site a video obtained by reporter  Bitsey Bloom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light applause. The TV is mounted on the wall in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitsey watches the report with about a dozen colleagues. Kruger stands beside her. A few people congratulate her. She attempts a smile and nods, though she doesn't look aw from the TV. Kruger shushes the others to hear the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The footage appears to show Constance  Harraway commit suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloom reports she received the tape  Friday morning at a motel in  Huntsville, where she was staying  while conducting Gale's last  interview.

dialogues.speaker: ON FLOOR
dialogues.text: Zack watches Bitsey from the other side of the room. She  looks over at him, then quickly looks back at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tape apparently had been in the  possession of a former DeathWatch  Director...

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: Camera pulls back to reveal that Roberts is standing in f of Wright's cabin. Other journalists and gawkers can be s out front. Police vehicles are also visible. Suits and officers move in and out of the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading the name off  a card) ...Dustin Emil Wright. As you can  see, police and officials from the  State Attorney's office have been in  and out of his cabin all morning,  looking for clues to his whereabouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belyeu enters a men's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belyeu walks to a row of sinks. He sets the case on the f and starts to wash his hands. A businessman combs his hai to Belyeu's left. Belyeu looks in the mirror and sees Dus approach from a stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room watches Roberts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a fanatic in the movement to stop  the death penalty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It appears Wright withheld the tape  to make an obscure political point  about the potential for error in  capital cases.

dialogues.speaker: ON BITSEY
dialogues.text: She watches, trying to contain her emotions. Zack watches her. She looks his direction. He smiles sadl looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty washes his hands, looks down at the case. The  businessman leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passport and ticket as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Governor Hardin is on the steps of the capital, journalis around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a tragedy for all of us.  As to whether this will change policy,  the people of Texas will have to  decide. Right now, the prudent course  is to put things on hold pendin' a  procedural review, allow ourselves  time to mourn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kruger leans toward Bitsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet she'll review. Capital  punishment approval rates dropped 17  points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitsey just looks at the TV, trying to make it through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty picks up the case. Belyeu straightens his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking past him) Go to the opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old footage of David being led in chains from an Austin  jailhouse to a waiting van. He wears the clothes he was  wearing the day Constance died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, the ultimate irony is  that David Gale, a man who became an  unwitting martyr, may achieve in  death what he worked for in life.

dialogues.speaker: ON BITSEY
dialogues.text: She bites her lower lip in a manner reminiscent of Consta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty walks along the Ramblan. He carries a duty-free bag and the aluminum suitcase. He comes to a building, checks its number against a piece of paper, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty ascends a staircase onto hallway. He walks a few st to door number six. An OLD SPANISH WOMAN passes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senorita Gale esta viviendo aqui?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. Si.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gracias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old woman moves down the stairs. Dusty puts the alumi suitcase on the doormat. From the duty-free bag he takes David's Yale sweatshirt, lays it over the case. He RINGS DOORBELL, turns and walks back down the hall. He stands at the top of the stairs, waiting for someone t answer before descending. Sharon (older than we've seen h opens the door, sees the case and sweatshirt. She looks  around, but Dusty is gone. She picks them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitsey sits at her neurotically neat desk, looking out th window. It's a sunny day in New York. For the first time, see her wearing something besides a business suit. Framed her cubicle wall is the latest News cover page: a picture David with the headline "The Executed Innocent." A MAIL GUY drops a Fed Ex package on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This just came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from "Belyeu & Crane/420 Congress Ave./Austin, T 78710." She opens it, pulls out Cloud Dog and a handwritt note on Belyeu & Crane stationery.

dialogues.speaker: NOTE
dialogues.text: reads: "David wanted you to have this. He said it would b the key to your freedom. Regards, Benjamin Belyeu."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the breakfast table, a Spanish yuppie male sits with a newspaper in front of him. He watches Sharon open the cas Inside: money, stacks and stacks of money. On top is an  unsigned note: "I'm sorrier than you can know."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitsey holds the stuffed sheep. puzzled. Looks at the note,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Key to your freedom? Key to your...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, she understands. She squeezes the sheep, shakes it, hears something. She cuts the sheep open with scissor A Hi-8 tape is in the stuffing. It's hand labeled: "Off t record." She jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: Bitsey hurries THROUGH the cubicles. She goes DOWN a hall and INTO the "MultiMedia" room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitsey locks the door, puts the tape into a Hi-8 deck.

dialogues.speaker: ON VIDEO
dialogues.text: The tape is cued to where Dusty picks up Constance's robe and walks past the tripod out of frame. We see only  Constance's body. We hear the sliding door to the patio o behind the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat. FOOTSTEPS on the patio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to turn this off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David walks into frame. He goes a couple of steps toward  Constance's body and stops, facing her. We see him only f behind. He looks at her, runs his hands over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She preferred it that way. You were  right about not tellin' her the whole  plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It helped her to think her death  would save me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you want to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Almost martyrs don't count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better go ahead then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David goes to Constance, kneels. He reaches down and with his thumb gently strokes her face through the plastic. He stands, turns and walks back to the camera. He reaches be the lens to turn it off. A beat. Half his face fills fram his watery eyes looking directly at us. In the other half we see Constance's body. Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty sits watching a performance of Puccini's Turandot. On stage is the scene where Liu martyrs herself.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTY
dialogues.text: He closes his eyes.
